p: Here you can find useful resources for your every-day sysadmin duties!
You can navigate by topic using the left-side menu or perform a site-wide search using the search box on the top right corner.
If you prefer to see all the articles at glance, here it is a list divided by topic:
Topic

How to install VMware ESXi on unsupported CPU (s)
SYS-VMW-00001
How to permanently allow VMware ESXi boot on unsupported CPU (s)

l: How to install VMware ESXi on unsupported CPU (s)

p: The installation of VMware ESXi fails with a message similar to the following:
Unsupported CPU: Intel family 0x06, model 0x1a, stepping 0x4
Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-4620 v 4 @ 2.10GHz
See http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility
You are trying to install a version of ESXi which is not marked as supported for your hardware CPUs (refer to: http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility).

While installing an unsupported version of ESXi may lead to compatibility issues, this doesn’t mean it’s not gonna work at all. This could be especially useful for a “homelab”, but heavily discouraged for a production environment.
To work around the problem, follow these steps:
Power off the hardware and boot into the installation media again
Click SHIFT+ O during the ESXi boot screen (“Loading ESXi Installer” is shown on top of the screen)
Type allowLegacyCPU=true without deleting anything. It should look like this:
Press ENTER to continue with the installation process
Further during the installation process you will come around a warning message like this:
<CPU_SUPPORT WARNIG: The CPU in this host is not supported by ESXi 7.0.0. Please refer to the VMware Compatibility Guide (VCG) for the list of supported CPUs.>
you can simply ignore this message by pressing ENTER.
You have now successfully installed VMware ESXi on an unsupported CPU!
This workaround is NOT permanent, as at the next startup you will need to type “allowLegacyCPU=true” during the boot process to allow ESXi to function properly.

To avoid doing this every time, see “How to permanently allow VMware ESXi boot on unsupported CPUs #SYS-VMW-00002“). The prerequisite is having already installed ESXi on the system by following the steps of this guide.
SYS-VMW-00001

l: How to permanently allow VMware ESXi boot on unsupported CPU (s)

p: You successfully installed VMware ESXi on hardware with an unsupported CPU following the steps of this guide: “How to install VMware ESXi on unsupported CPUs #SYS-VMW-00001” but after a reboot you’re stuck with an error message like this:
Unsupported CPU: Intel family 0x06, model 0x1a, stepping 0x4
Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-4620 v 4 @ 2.10GHz
See http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility
You installed a version of ESXi which is not marked as supported for your hardware CPUs (refer to: http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility).

Remember, this workaround applies to you if you have ALREADY installed ESXi on hardware with unsupported CPUs. If you have not installed ESXi yet, please refer to “How to install VMware ESXi on unsupported CPUs #SYS-VMW-00001” first.
Shut down the ESXi server
Remove the media where ESXi is installed on (might be an USB, a SD card or a SSD/HDD)
Plug the media into a PC running Windows or any other OS capable of working on FAT filesystems
You will see two partitions, one containing ONLY a file named BOOT.CFG and another with several files including another BOOT.CFG
Open the BOOT.CFG contained in the partition WITH MULTIPLE FILES with a text editor
Find the line starting with “kernelopt=” and add “allowLegacyCPU=true” at the end of the line, like this: BOOT.CGF
Save the file
Insert the boot media back into the server
Boot the server. If everything worked correctly ESXi should now boot automatically without the need to pass the “AllowLegacyCPU=true” parameter manually each time.
This workaround is permanent, but doesn’t mean you won’t experience unexpected behavior in the future since this configuration is not officially supported.
This workaround can be applied to virtualized (nested) ESXi hosts too by working on the .vmdk file.
SYS-VMW-00002

l: Active Directory: prevent Domain Users to join computers into domain

p: You might have noticed that users that are not members of the Domain Admin group are adding computers to the AD domain
TIP: You can look for event ID 4741 in the Domain Controller “Security” event log to see who added a computer to the domain
This is expected behavior. Members of the Domain Users group can add up to 10 computers to the AD domain
To prevent Domain Users to add computers to the domain there are 2 possible solutions: editing the ms-DS-MachineAccountQuota attribute or via GPO.
Open Active Directory Users and Computers ( dsa.msc)
On the menu click on “ View” then tick the option “ Advanced Features“
Right click on your domain name on the right column, then “ Properties“
Click on the “ Attribute Editor” tab
Find the “ ms-DS-MachineAccountQuota“, click “ Edit“
Set the value from 10 to 0, then save
You can check if the modification is working by either trying to add a computer to the domain with an unprivileged user account credentials or by running this PowerShell script:

l: Method 2 – Editing the Domain Controllers default group policy
p: Open Group Policy Management Console ( gpmc.msc)
Locate the “ Domain Controllers” OU and expand it
Right click on “ Default Domain Controllers Policy” then “ Edit”
Expand:
Computer Configuration
Policies
Windows Settings
Security Settings
Local Policies
User Rights Assignment
Find the policy named “ Add workstations to domain” The Group Policy Management Console
Edit the policy by removing the “ Authenticated Users” group and adding the security group delegated to adding workstations to the domain
Click “ Apply” and “ Ok”, then close the Group Policy Management Console
You can read more about the ms-DS-MachineAccountQuota attribute on the official MS documentation
SYS-WIN-00001

l: How to bypass Windows PowerShell scripts execution policies

p: When you try to execute a PowerShell script, you get the following error message:
You came from the guide “How to open PowerShell scripts with a double-click #SYS-WIN-00002” and when you double click a PowerShell script it closes without a warning
The ability to run PowerShell scripts on the system is influenced by Execution Policies. You can refer to the official Microsoft documentation to learn more about it (about Execution Policies).
The default execution policy for the “ LocalMachine” scope is “ Restricted“

Execution policies are an important security feature on Windows, they can be applied to different scopes(as the official documentation says: “ On a Windows computer you can set an execution policy for the local computer, for the current user, or for a particular session.”) and can be set up via group policies when the computer/server is domain joined. The aim of this guide is SOLELY to make you able to quickly run a PowerShell script on your system, remember that setting up proper execution policies is mandatory to keep your OS safe.
That begin said, here are the steps to follow:
( OPTIONAL) Open a PowerShell and run the following command to get a list of the system’s current execution policies:
Open an elevated PowerShell ( run as Administrator) and run the following command:
Notice how we are not specifying to which scope we want to apply the “ Unrestricted” policy to. That’s because if not otherwise specified the default scope is “ LocalMachine“.
Press Y when prompted
You can now execute the script. If you still encounter problems, the issue lies somewhere else and you will need to analyze the error message to investigate the issue further.
A PowerShell prompt

As stated before messing around with execution policies is not recommended if you don’t have a general idea of what you’re doing, so apply this quick workaround only for the time necessary to run your scripts.
Here is a list of official Microsoft documentation on the topic that you might find useful:
Get-ExecutionPolicy
Set-ExecutionPolicy
About Execution Policies
SYS-WIN-00003

l: How to open PowerShell scripts with a double click

p: When you double click a PowerShell script it opens up in the notepad or in the PowerShell ISE instead of executing
This is expected behavior. This can be changed by following the steps below.
There are several ways to achieve the result, but the following appears to be the easiest one without having to edit registry keys or other system parameters.
Right click the script you intend to execute
Select “ Open with...” and then “ Chose another app“
Flag the option “ Always use this app to open .ps1 files” then click on “ More apps” and finally on “ Look for another app on this pc”
Navigate to the default PowerShell install directory “ C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0“
Select “ powershell.exe” then “ Open”
An example of how the icon of .ps1 files changes after the modification
That’s it, from now on a double click will automatically fire .ps1 scripts instead opening them in the editor.

If your script doesn’t run when double clicked ( it closes without a warning) and you are sure the problem doesn’t lays in the script itself, you might want to have a look into the current setup of the execution policies of your system. If you need guidance on it, you can follow the steps on “How to check and edit Windows scripts execution policies #SYS-WIN-00003“
SYS-WIN-00002

The purpose of this project is simply sharing useful guides, tools, workarounds and many more with you other fellow SysAdmins out there. If you want to contribute or report an issue, feel free to do so by opening a GitHub issue or by sending an email
The website itself is served through GitHub pages, you can learn more about it here. It resides on my personal repository, EarlyOwl/earlyowl.github.io and it's reachable at:
earlyowl.github.io(my username)
sosyadmin.com(the project name, custom domain)
The documentation is all written in GitHub markdown format and then converted into a standard (HTML) website thanks to Retype. You can check it out on the official repo retypeapp/retype.
My GitHub profile
This project repository
Want to report an issue, contribute or have any question?
Feel free to contact me at sosysadmin[at] proton.me
